fr:mainmatter.html:p:
There are a few different concepts of ghosts and phantoms in homotopy theory.
In the unstable world, a ghost map f : X \to Y between CW-complexes is a non-zero map that cannot be detected via homotopy groups (or more generally finite CW-complexes), i.e. all compositions Z \to X \to Y with Z finite are null-homotopic.
In the stable case, a map between spectra is a (co)homology phantom if all the induced maps on the (co)homology of finite CW-complexes is zero.
A stronger condition is given by requiring the induced maps on the (co)homology of all spaces (equivalently, all suspension spectra, possibly with some desuspensions) are zero. This is called a superphantom map.
We can have an even stronger condition, requiring triviality on all spectra. Let’s temporarily call this a (co)homology ultraphantom map.

Obviously, when we pass to the stable world, ghost maps becomes cohomology phantom maps. By Spanier–Whitehead duality, we can replace finite CW-complexes with their duals, thus establishing that the cohomology and homology phantom maps are identical. On the other hand, it is impossible to have a cohomology ultraphantom map f : X \to Y, since the identity cohomology class \iota : X \to X will be sent to zero, meaning f itself is null-homotopic. Similarly, a ghost map cannot give a cohomology superphantom map.

Since homology preserves filtered colimits, every homology superphantom map comes from a phantom map, and vice versa. Similarly, we can extend this to ultraphantom maps. Therefore these three concepts collapse into one, and the phrases phantom maps and superphantom maps suffices to unambiguously refer to all of these concepts.

fr:title.text: phantom maps K(\mathbb {Q}, n) \to K(\mathbb {Z}, n+1)

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: phantom maps K(\mathbb {Q}, n) \to K(\mathbb {Z}, n+1)

fr:mainmatter.html:p: By construction, the homotopy classes of maps f : K(\mathbb {Q}, n) \to K(\mathbb {Z}, n+1) corresponds to elements \operatorname {Ext}(\mathbb {Q}, \mathbb {Z}). However, any map from a finite CW-complex into K(\mathbb {Q}, n) lifts to K(A, n) where A \subseteq \mathbb {Q} is finitely generated. But \operatorname {Ext}(A, \mathbb {Z}) = 0. This means f is a ghost, and consequently a phantom H \mathbb {Q} \to \Sigma H \mathbb {Z}.

fr:title.text: a superphantom map KU \to \Sigma H \mathbb Z

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: a superphantom map KU \to \Sigma H \mathbb Z

fr:mainmatter.html:p: For the complex K-theory spectrum KU, the integral homology is given by H_{2n} (K U) = \mathbb {Q}, and the odd degrees are zero. Therefore H^1 (KU) = \operatorname {Ext}(\mathbb {Q}, \mathbb {Z}) by the universal coefficient theorem. Pick a non-zero map \theta : KU \to \Sigma H \mathbb {Z}. We claim it is a cohomology superphantom map.

Consider any space X. Cohomology classes \omega \in KU(X) correspond to (formal sums of) vector bundles on X, and the image in H^1 (X; \mathbb {Z}) assigns a characteristic class \theta (\omega ) for each vector bundle. Consider the universal example, the tautological bundle \tau on BU(n). All vector bundles come from the pullback of a map f : X \to BU(n), and the characteristic class will also come from the pullback f^* \theta (\tau ) of the universal characteristic class. However, H^1 (BU(n)) = 0, so this cohomology operation vanishes on all spaces.

fr:title.text: phantom maps K(\mathbb {Q}, n) \to K(\mathbb {Z}, n+1)

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: phantom maps K(\mathbb {Q}, n) \to K(\mathbb {Z}, n+1)

fr:mainmatter.html:p: By construction, the homotopy classes of maps f : K(\mathbb {Q}, n) \to K(\mathbb {Z}, n+1) corresponds to elements \operatorname {Ext}(\mathbb {Q}, \mathbb {Z}). However, any map from a finite CW-complex into K(\mathbb {Q}, n) lifts to K(A, n) where A \subseteq \mathbb {Q} is finitely generated. But \operatorname {Ext}(A, \mathbb {Z}) = 0. This means f is a ghost, and consequently a phantom H \mathbb {Q} \to \Sigma H \mathbb {Z}.

fr:title.text: a superphantom map KU \to \Sigma H \mathbb Z

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: a superphantom map KU \to \Sigma H \mathbb Z

fr:mainmatter.html:p: For the complex K-theory spectrum KU, the integral homology is given by H_{2n} (K U) = \mathbb {Q}, and the odd degrees are zero. Therefore H^1 (KU) = \operatorname {Ext}(\mathbb {Q}, \mathbb {Z}) by the universal coefficient theorem. Pick a non-zero map \theta : KU \to \Sigma H \mathbb {Z}. We claim it is a cohomology superphantom map.

Consider any space X. Cohomology classes \omega \in KU(X) correspond to (formal sums of) vector bundles on X, and the image in H^1 (X; \mathbb {Z}) assigns a characteristic class \theta (\omega ) for each vector bundle. Consider the universal example, the tautological bundle \tau on BU(n). All vector bundles come from the pullback of a map f : X \to BU(n), and the characteristic class will also come from the pullback f^* \theta (\tau ) of the universal characteristic class. However, H^1 (BU(n)) = 0, so this cohomology operation vanishes on all spaces.
This is my forest. Forests are a way of organizing notes, and here is a list of other websites organized as forests. Some of the contents here:

fr:link.title: Generating aperiodic tilings with substitution systems

html:li.fr:link: Generating aperiodic tilings with substitution systems

html:ul.html:li: Algebraic geometry (Under namespace algm, not organized)

fr:mainmatter.html:p: On a computer, you can press Ctrl–K to search for trees.
I try to adhere to several principles when composing trees.

html:ul.html:li: If a definition or a lemma would present itself during a proof attempt, then do not introduce it until that part of the proof. The nature of forests makes this kind of organization more viable, as each definition is a tree by itself.
If a part of a proof has an easy constructive phrasing, use it and avoid classical reasoning. But if it requires some complication, then the classical way is used.

Avoid abstraction leaks. Even if A is defined as B, do not use them interchangeably. For instance, an ideal is defined as a subset of a ring satisfying certain conditions. But we will insist on writing ideals as numbers, for example saying \mathfrak {a} \mid x instead of x \in \mathfrak {a}. This is not too heretic, since algebraic number theory already uses this kind of notation. Similarly, although prime ideals correspond to points in \operatorname {Spec}(A), we do not identify them.
Apply unbiased terminology and negative thinking.
